title: 115_hr5796
content: The "Responsible Education Achieves Care and Healthy Outcomes for Users' Treatment Act of 2018" or the "REACH OUT Act of 2018" grants technical assistance to outlier prescribers of opioids. The "REACH OUT Act of 2018" authorizes grants to educate outlier opioid prescribers on best practices, non-opioid pain management, and reducing opioid prescriptions. Eligible entities can apply for grants through technical assistance. Each eligible entity must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant, contract, or cooperative agreement. The Secretary will prioritize establishing technical assistance resources in each State when awarding grants. Eligible entities are organizations with experience providing technical assistance to healthcare professionals on a State or regional basis. The term "outlier prescriber of opioids" refers to a prescriber identified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services based on provided prescriber information. The Social Security Act allows for monitoring prescribers who exceed opioid thresholds, with funding of $75 for implementation. Prescribers include licensed health care professionals like nurse practitioners and physician assistants. $75 million from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund is allocated for implementing monitoring of prescribers who exceed opioid thresholds under the Social Security Act. SEC. 3. PROMOTING VALUE IN MEDICAID MANAGED CARE. Section 1903(m) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust the Federal medical assistance percentage for State expenditures on medical assistance after fiscal year 2025. The State incurs costs for medical assistance provided to individuals by managed care entities or specified entities, treated as remittances if the State meets certain requirements regarding minimum medical loss ratios. The State must meet a minimum medical loss ratio of 85 percent for payments to managed care entities. A State meeting this requirement as of May 31, 2018, is eligible. The term 'managed care entity' refers to a Medicaid managed care organization. The term 'minimum medical loss ratio' in a State refers to a ratio for payment for services provided by certain entities under the State plan. The term 'other specified entity' includes prepaid inpatient and ambulatory health plans. Passed the House of Representatives June 19, 2018. Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
